thread.title: Season ends short of state title for Trinity, Heritage
thread.title_full: Season ends short of state title for Trinity, Heritage

title: Season ends short of state title for Trinity, Heritage
text:
Season ends short of state title for Trinity, Heritage by Comments 
Trinity junior Cheyenne Hayes watches the flight of her spike split through an OMA double block. 
Whenever Trinity Christian and Oak Mountain volleyball team have met this season, the intensity was at a high. 
Nothing changed Saturday as the two squads battled for the GISA state title at The Heritage School for the second consecutive season. 
A year ago, Trinity swept to the state crown (25-16, 25-21, 25-21) en route to the program’s fourth consecutive GISA volleyball title. 
In this year’s rematch Oak Mountain held off a determined Trinity squad (25-23, 22-25, 25-21, 25-18) to get some revenge. 
Earlier in the day, Trinity advanced to the championship with a victory over rival Heritage School in the semifinals (25-23, 25-21, 25-12) in a match that was close for the first two sets before the Lady Lions dominated the last game, while Oak Mountain beat Loganville Christian. 
“These girls have been together from the start and have worked hard from the “get go,” Trinity head coach Joe Herrera said. They are a special group of young ladies. I can’t ask for anything else.” 
The game ended on a sour note for Trinity when senior Chasey Mitchell was carried off late in the fourth set with what Herrera called a knee injury. 
It was the fourth meeting this year between the GISA Region 1-AAA rivals, with the Lady Warriors winning for the third time including in the region championship. 
The Lady Lions were led offensively by junior Cheyenne Hayes throughout the day. 
Before getting hurt late in the game, Mitchell helped keep several points alive with her defensive effort. 
Senior libero Kelsey Richards also turned in a solid effort with some impressive digs. 
Seniors Peyton Lohlein, Libby Rogers, Jones, Mitchell, and Richards helped turn the Lady Lions into a dynasty. 
“They mean so much, they have helped establish the program,” said Herrera, who closed his first season as head coach with a 32-5 record after taking over the coaching reigns from Joe Camp this season. 
In the first set, Oak Mountain jumped out front 22-16 before Hayes brought the Lady Lions back with a kill. 
Trinity got as close as two points when Ava Taylor put a shot away and trimmed the lead to 23-21. 
Trinity took control of the second set early, and led 17-10 before Oak Mountain made a run. 
The Lady Warriors trimmed the lead to 23-21, before Trinity was able to close out the match. 
Trinity and Oak Mountain traded leads in the third set with the Lady Lions building a 12-10 lead. 
Oak Mountain, however, fought back to take a 15-14 lead at never trailed again to build a 2-1 set advantage in the match. 
After pulling away 7-6 in the fourth set, Oak Mountain never trailed again and to secure its state title. 
Oak Mountain’s Bret Luther and Kendall Washington led the way for the Lady Warriors. 
Against Heritage, the Lady Lions exchanged the lead four times in the first set with Heritage building its largest lead at 8-5, before Trinity ral- lied back to eventually tie the game at 9-9. 
The Lady Lions took the lead for good when they pulled out to an 10-9 lead. 
Trinity eventually pulled out to a five-point lead twice at 14-9 lead 16-11 before Heritage l stormed back to tie the game for a final time at 20-20. The two teams traded points the rest of the way before the Lady Lions secured the win. 
The second set was nearly a repeat of the first set with the two teams exchanging the momentum early. After five ties, including the final one at 8-all, the Lady Lions took their first lead of the match at 9-8. 
The Lady Lions extended the margin to 18-13, but the Lady Hawks went on a 6-0 run to grab a 19-18 lead. 
Heritage had a chance to tie the match at a set apiece when it went up 21-19, but Trinity scored the next six points. 
The Lady Lions dominated the third set leading from start to finish and after build- ing its first double-digit lead at 14-4 the set was never in doubt. 
“I thought we played really hard against a very good Trinity team,” Heritage head coach Mary Louise Hunt said. 
It was the last high school volleyball match for Heritage seniors Morgan Tiernan, Dottie Hall and Hallie Hunt. 
“I am going to miss the seniors,” Hunt said. “They have worked really hard.” More
